skill.name: diffdock
skill.description: Diffusion-based molecular docking. Predict protein-ligand binding poses from PDB/SMILES, confidence scores, virtual screening, for structure-based drug design. Not for affinity prediction.
skill.summary: Diffusion-based molecular docking. Predict protein-ligand binding poses from PDB/SMILES, confidence ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: The static analysis flagged 295 potential issues, but ALL are FALSE POSITIVES. The scanner incorrectly identified scientific protein sequences (GFP containing 'SAM') as Windows SAM database references, scientific paper citations as weak cryptographic algorithms, standard Python loops as C2 beacon patterns, and markdown code block syntax as shell execution. This is a legitimate molecular docking research tool with no malicious intent or security vulnerabilities.

content.user_title: Predict molecular binding poses with AI docking
content.value_statement: DiffDock uses advanced diffusion models to predict how small molecules bind to proteins in 3D space. Researchers can accelerate drug discovery by generating accurate binding poses with confidence scores for structure-based drug design.
actual_capabilities: Predict 3D binding poses from PDB files and SMILES strings
Generate confidence scores for each docking prediction
Process batch virtual screening campaigns with multiple ligands
Support protein sequences via ESMFold integration
Export results in SDF format for visualization and downstream analysis
limitations: Predicts binding poses only, not binding affinity or strength
Requires GPU for practical performance on large campaigns
Limited to small molecules typically 100-1000 Da
Not suitable for protein-protein or large biomolecule docking

use_cases.title: Virtual screening campaigns
use_cases.description: Screen thousands of compounds against target proteins to identify promising drug candidates for further study

use_cases.title: Binding site prediction
use_cases.description: Predict where small molecules bind to protein structures to understand mechanisms and guide experiments

use_cases.title: Lead optimization
use_cases.description: Generate binding poses for compound modifications to improve interactions with target proteins

prompt_templates.title: Basic single docking
prompt_templates.scenario: Dock a ligand to a protein
prompt_templates.prompt: Dock the ligand COc1ccc(C(=O)Nc2ccccc2)cc1 to the protein in protein.pdb and save results to results/docking/

prompt_templates.title: Batch screening
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a batch CSV for screening 50 compounds against protein.pdb, then run DiffDock with 20 samples per complex

prompt_templates.title: Analyze results
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the confidence scores from DiffDock results in results/batch/ and show the top 10 predictions

prompt_templates.title: Custom parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom config for docking flexible ligands with increased temperature and 30 inference steps

output: Generated 10 binding poses for aspirin-COX-2 complex
Binding site: Active site near residues Arg120 and Tyr355
Review recommended: Visualize top 3 poses for structural plausibility

output_examples.input: Screen library of 100 fragments against kinase target
output: Processed 100 ligand-protein complexes with 20 samples each
Mean processing time: 45 seconds per complex on GPU
High confidence hits: 12 compounds with score above 0

best_practices: Always validate environment with setup_check.py before large batch jobs
Use 20-40 samples per complex for important predictions
Combine with scoring functions like GNINA for affinity estimation
Visualize top 3-5 poses to check for structural plausibility
anti_patterns: Using confidence scores as direct binding affinity measurements
Running large virtual screening without GPU access
Assuming single prediction is correct without examining alternatives
Ignoring protein preparation and missing residue issues

faq.question: What is the difference between confidence and affinity?
faq.answer: Confidence measures how certain the model is about the predicted pose. Affinity measures binding strength. High confidence does not mean strong binding.

faq.question: How many samples should I generate per complex?
faq.answer: Use 10 for quick screening, 20-40 for important predictions, and 40+ for very flexible or large ligands.

faq.question: Can I use protein sequences instead of PDB files?
faq.answer: Yes, DiffDock uses ESMFold to predict protein structure from sequence. PDB files typically give better results though.

faq.question: What ligand formats are supported?
faq.answer: SMILES strings, SDF files, and MOL2 files. SMILES are most convenient for high-throughput screening.

faq.question: How do I interpret negative confidence scores?
faq.answer: Scores below -1.5 indicate low confidence. Consider more samples, ensemble docking, or experimental validation.

faq.question: Can DiffDock predict binding affinity?
faq.answer: No, DiffDock only predicts binding poses. Use GNINA, MM/GBSA, or experimental methods for affinity prediction.
